[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, complex sentence structures (e.g., multiple embedded clauses).
[LEXICON]: Archaisms ("travel-soiled," "wonder-working") may slightly impede modern readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from pilgrimage themes (Chapter I) to pre-Roman history (Chapter II) without explicit bridging.
[STRUCTURE]: Chapter II’s detailed historical exposition feels somewhat disconnected from Chapter I’s thematic focus.

[ANACHRONISM]: Historical inaccuracies (e.g., Ethelbert’s 6th-century activities described with 18th-century artistic references).
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt topic shifts (e.g., from Canterbury to unrelated governance system).

[STRUCTURE]: Disjointed narrative with unrelated segments (e.g., "t'umu" description disrupts historical continuity).
[LOGIC]: Inconsistent contextual relevance (e.g., modern artistic activities attributed to a medieval king).

[SYNTAX]: Extremely long, complex sentence structures (e.g., first paragraph of current segment) may impede smooth reading.
[LEXICON]: Abrupt, uncontextualized dialogue ("Cecil and I...") disrupts narrative flow.

[TRANSITION]: Sudden shifts between historical description (e.g., Dean Stanley reference) and immediate events (e.g., Becket’s murder scene).
[STRUCTURE]: Unresolved contextual gap (e.g., "Cecil" dialogue appears unrelated to surrounding narrative).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex sentence structures (e.g., "the marks of the stripes administered on the previous day being plainly visible").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unconnected scene shift (romantic dialogue after historical narrative).
[CLARITY]: Unclear, isolated quote ("Therefore let my brother send gold...") without contextual integration.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures in descriptive passages, slightly hindering smooth reading flow.

[LOGIC]: Abrupt, unrelated biographical paragraph about Reynolds disrupts thematic continuity.

[SYNTAX]: No significant syntactic errors; complex sentences are well-structured.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unrelated topics (e.g., Grant/Lee, Marie, prehistoric hunter) disrupt thematic continuity.
[TRANSITION]: No logical connections between disparate sections.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., multiple nested clauses) that slightly impede smooth flow.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between topics (e.g., wall description to Abbey history without clear connectors).
